title: How to Restore and Revive Suede At Home

steps.title: Remove the laces and insert shoe trees before brushing suede shoes.
steps.content: Remove the laces and insert shoe trees before brushing suede shoes. Taking the shoelaces out of your suede shoes will make it easier for you to brush them thoroughly. Either place a shoe tree in each shoe before you brush it, or stuff the shoes with newspaper so they keep their shape. [1] X Research source You can find shoe trees at your local big box store or online. Re-lace the shoes once you're completely finished brushing them.

steps.title: Select a suede brush with soft bristles to restore the nap.
steps.content: Select a suede brush with soft bristles to restore the nap. Purchase a suede brush —a special cleaning brush designed specifically for suede. [2] X Research source These brushes have soft bristles that will clean the suede without damaging it and restore the nap texture in the process—whether the suede has gone smooth from wear or feels rough and gritty because of age and grime. [3] X Research source Purchase a large suede cleaning brush if you're restoring something like a suede sofa. A smaller cleaning brush will work well on things like shoes or purses. A soft-bristled toothbrush or nail brush will work too, as long as they’re clean.

steps.title: Brush the suede material using gentle swiping motions.
steps.content: Brush the suede material using gentle swiping motions. Stroke the suede with the cleaning brush using gentle sweeping motions. Only brush in the direction of the fibers (the grain), and avoid back-and-forth strokes. Brush until you’ve covered the entire surface. This will remove any dust or dirt on the suede without causing damage. [4] X Research source Only brush completely dry suede. Let stains dry before brushing. Otherwise, you risk rubbing dirt and grime particles deeper into the material. [5] X Research source Brush your suede weekly to keep it looking fresh.

steps.title: Absorb liquid stains right after they happen, if possible.
steps.content: Absorb liquid stains right after they happen, if possible. If you spill something on your suede or it otherwise gets wet, use a paper towel or clean microfiber cloth to blot up the moisture as soon as possible, says home cleaning specialist Daniel Olin. [6] X Expert Source Daniel Olin Home Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 12 October 2021. This prevents the wet stain from setting and drying on your suede, which would make it harder to get out. [7] X Research source After blotting, let the suede air dry for a few hours.

steps.title: Dab white vinegar on tough stains with a cloth to clean them.
steps.content: Dab white vinegar on tough stains with a cloth to clean them. Dampen a clean cloth with white vinegar and gently dab the dirt or other grime stains with it. Saturate the area where the stain is and then let the white vinegar dry completely. Once it’s dry, rub the stain off with a suede brush or soft-bristled toothbrush until the dirt is all gone. [8] X Research source If you’re cleaning suede shoes, put shoe trees or pieces of newspaper in the shoes to help them keep their shape and protect the interior lining of the shoe. Olin says another option is to use gentle laundry detergent, blotting it onto the stain with a microfiber cloth rag and absorbing it with another dry rag. [9] X Expert Source Daniel Olin Home Cleaning Specialist Expert Interview. 12 October 2021.

steps.title: Purchase a suede eraser to rub off tricky stains.
steps.content: Purchase a suede eraser to rub off tricky stains. Suede erasers are designed specifically for suede materials and can help you get rid of many types of stains. Rub the eraser on the suede stain using circular motions until the stain disappears, leaving you with clean suede. [10] X Research source Dealing with permanent marker stains? Use suede gum to try to remove it, says designer shoe and bag repair specialist Rio Jongsae Kim. [11] X Expert Source Rio Jongsae Kim Designer Shoe & Bag Care Specialist Expert Interview. 15 April 2021. You can use a Magic Eraser, which is mostly baking soda, on suede. Spot test it on a small, unnoticeable part of the shoe before treating any stains to see how it reacts. [12] X Research source Brush off the eraser hairs and use a vacuum to pick them up if there are a lot.

steps.title: Sand suede using 1200-grit sandpaper to get rid of stubborn stains.
steps.content: Sand suede using 1200-grit sandpaper to get rid of stubborn stains. Use a piece of 1200-grit sandpaper on the suede so it’s not too abrasive. Rub the sandpaper against the stain gently to scrape it off, moving the sandpaper over the soiled patch evenly for a uniform look. Swipe with a suede brush afterward to restore the nap texture. [13] X Research source Sanding your suede aggressively can damage it, so work gently and carefully. Brush any remaining dirt off using a suede brush once you’re finished sanding.

steps.title: Cover the suede in a thin layer of clean water to fix water stains.
steps.content: Cover the suede in a thin layer of clean water to fix water stains. If you have a water stain on your suede bag, jacket, or furniture, the best way to get rid of it is to dampen the rest of the suede with water (not saturate it!) to even it out. Dampen a towel with water and dab the water onto your suede, covering all of it evenly. Once this layer of water dries overnight, the stain shouldn’t be visible anymore. [14] X Research source If you think you might have applied too much water, use a dry microfiber cloth or paper towel to absorb some of the excess moisture. Let the suede dry naturally—avoid putting it near a heat source that could make it shrink or crack. If you’re cleaning suede shoes, put a shoe tree or piece of newspaper in the shoe so it keeps its shape.

steps.title: Sprinkle cornstarch or talcum powder over grease stains to fix them.
steps.content: Sprinkle cornstarch or talcum powder over grease stains to fix them. Sprinkle cornstarch or talcum powder onto the grease or other tricky oil-based stain to cover the entire stained area, says Kim. Let the cornstarch or powder sit overnight and vacuum it up or brush it off with a suede brush the next day to reveal clean suede. [15] X Research source Use your hands to pat the cornstarch or talcum powder into the stain to help it work better. Use a thick layer of cornstarch or talcum powder to be sure it absorbs as much as possible.

steps.title: Treat suede with a waterproofing spray to repel common stains.
steps.content: Treat suede with a waterproofing spray to repel common stains. Purchase a suede protectant or waterproofing spray to make it easier to keep your suede material clean. Hold the spray bottle 3–5 inches (7.6–12.7 cm) from the suede and apply it evenly to the fabric. Cover the suede in two to three coats, letting each coat dry before adding another one. [16] X Research source Test a small area of the suede before you cover all of it to be sure it works and won’t discolor your specific suede item. Suede protectant sprays are often silicone-based and come in a clear color, so they’re not visible on your suede. Once you treat the suede, you shouldn't need to again for a few months or after you clean it again.

steps.title: Bring your suede to a leather cleaner if you can’t get the stain out.
steps.content: Bring your suede to a leather cleaner if you can’t get the stain out. Sometimes your suede may be too stained for you to restore it yourself. If you've tried to clean the stain and it wouldn't come out, take your suede item to a professional cleaner and ask them if they can get it out. This is also a good thing to do if you're worried about damaging the suede by trying to clean it yourself. This works well if you have a small suede item like a shoe, purse, or item of clothing.

steps.title: Maintain suede with regular care and proper storage.
steps.content: Maintain suede with regular care and proper storage. For any suede items you use year-round, like furniture, condition them with a waterproofing spray about once a month. For suede items that are seasonal, like shoes, jackets, and bags, use waterproofing spray at the start of the season and after every cleaning. Store these items in breathable containers like cotton garment bags to prevent moisture from building up and damaging the material. [17] X Research source Try to treat stains immediately to minimize damage to your suede.

steps.title: Can damaged suede be restored?
steps.content: Can damaged suede be restored? It’s possible to clean suede that’s been stained with water, dirt, or grease, and to restore the nap of suede that’s lost its signature texture. [18] X Research source However, damage like cracking or breakage may not be fixable. When in doubt, ask an expert before trying to fix it yourself. Consult a dry cleaner for suede clothing, a cobbler for suede shoes, and a furniture restoration expert for suede furniture.

steps.title: Why does my suede feel smooth?
steps.content: Why does my suede feel smooth? Suede has a smooth surface, but also a signature nap texture. If your suede turned smooth and lost its nap, it’s likely due to wear and exposure to the elements. Use a suede brush to restore the nap , swiping over the suede in gentle, straight strokes.

steps.title: How do you fix suede discoloration?
steps.content: How do you fix suede discoloration? Use a suede dye to fix suede that’s become discolored with age. Because it’s difficult to match the material’s coloring with spot-dying, it’s best to do an all-over dye. First, use a suede brush to remove any dirt and grime. [19] X Research source Next, remove the laces. Apply a suede cleaner for deeper stains. Finally, apply the suede dye by dabbing it on the shoe with a sponge. [20] X Research source Apply another coat of dye if needed. Verify that your suede is genuine before trying to dye it. Research different dyes to find one from a trusted company and follow the exact directions on the bottle, advises shoe care and repair specialist Moe Draper. [21] X Expert Source Moe Draper Shoe Care & Repair Specialist Expert Interview. 5 April 2021.

steps.title: How often should you waterproof suede?
steps.content: How often should you waterproof suede? Waterproof suede at the start of the season when you’ll be wearing them (typically, fall or winter). Apply a waterproof spray every time you clean them to restore their waterproof seal. If you’re wearing them in particularly wet conditions, waterproof once a month. [22] X Research source
